original_data.question: A 60-year-old man presents to his local walk-in clinic with 1 week of fever, chills, night sweats, anorexia, malaise, progressive shortness of breath, and sharp chest pain. He is found with a blood pressure of 100/80 mm Hg, a heart rate of 84/min, an elevated respiratory rate, and a holosystolic heart murmur III/VI. His palms and soles show non-tender erythematous lesions. His personal medical history is relevant for frequent visits to the ER for lower gastrointestinal bleeding in the last month with a recent colonoscopy that reported an ulcerative lesion suggestive of colorectal cancer. He has not been subjected to dental procedures recently, and he denies the use of psychoactive drugs. A chest plain film shows clear lungs and mild cardiomegaly, and echocardiography reports the presence of vegetations involving the mitral valve. Which of the following organisms is the most likely causative agent?

model_response:
The patient's clinical presentation is consistent with infective endocarditis. The presence of non-tender erythematous lesions on the palms and soles is suggestive of Janeway lesions, which are painless erythematous macules that occur in half of the patients with endocarditis. The causative agent is likely to be Staphylococcus aureus, which accounts for 20-30% of cases of native valve endocarditis. The most common predisposing factor for infective endocarditis is a previous history of bacteremia, which is frequently associated with a preexisting cardiac abnormality. In this case, the patient's history of colorectal cancer and lower gastrointestinal bleeding could have predisposed him to bacteremia. Other predisposing factors include intravenous drug use, hemodialysis, and prosthetic heart valves. The other microorganisms listed are not typically associated with infective endocarditis.

Escherichia coli is associated with infective endocarditis in patients with underlying structural cardiac abnormalities, especially those with a history of intravenous drug use. Haemophilus aphrophilus is associated with infective endocarditis in patients with underlying structural cardiac abnormalities, especially those with a history of intravenous drug use. Streptococcus bovis is associated with infective endocarditis in patients with underlying structural cardiac abnormalities, especially those with a history of intravenous drug use.

###Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Human males as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
A healthcare facility where an individual can visit a medical professional without needing an appointment.
Any period of seven consecutive days.
An abnormal elevation of body temperature, usually as a result of a pathologic process.
The sudden sensation of being cold. It may be accompanied by SHIVERING.
Perspiration experienced nocturnally that is unrelated to environmental temperature.
The lack or loss of APPETITE accompanied by an aversion to food and the inability to eat. It is the defining characteristic of the disorder ANOREXIA NERVOSA.
A feeling of general discomfort or uneasiness, an out-of-sorts feeling.
Advancing in extent or severity.
Height greater than two standard deviations below the mean of the appropriate reference population for the age and sex of the individual.
The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.
The sensation of chest pain described as a stabbing feeling.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A metric unit of length equal to one thousandth of a meter (10E-3 meter) or approximately 0.03937 inch.
The number of times the HEART VENTRICLES contract per unit of time, usually per minute.
An elevated level or position or degree; greater than normal in degree or intensity or amount.
The rate of breathing (inhalation and exhalation) measured within in a unit time, usually expressed as breaths per minute.
A heart murmur that occurs during the entire systolic interval, from the first to second heart sounds.
The palm family of order Arecales, subclass Arecidae, class Liliopsida.
The undersurface of the foot.
An indication of the severity of a lesion that has red discoloration.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.
Coming at short intervals or in great quantities.
The act of going to see some person or place or thing; it can cover a short or long period but refers to a non-permanent arrangement.

A system of cisternae in the CYTOPLASM of many cells. In places the endoplasmic reticulum is continuous with the plasma membrane (CELL MEMBRANE) or outer membrane of the nuclear envelope. If the outer surfaces of the endoplasmic reticulum membranes are coated with ribosomes, the endoplasmic reticulum is said to be rough-surfaced (ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM, ROUGH); otherwise it is said to be smooth-surfaced (ENDOPLASMIC RETICULUM, SMOOTH). (King & Stansfield, A Dictionary of Genetics, 4th ed)
Bleeding in any segment of the GASTROINTESTINAL TRACT from ESOPHAGUS to RECTUM.
Every month.
Endoscopic examination, therapy or surgery of the luminal surface of the colon.
A lesion on the surface of the skin or a mucous surface, produced by the sloughing of inflammatory necrotic tissue.
A localized pathological or traumatic structural change, damage, deformity, or discontinuity of tissue, organ, or body part.
A malignant epithelial neoplasm that arises from the colon or rectum and invades through the muscularis mucosa into the submucosa. The vast majority are adenocarcinomas.
The total of dental diagnostic, preventive, and restorative services provided to meet the needs of a patient (from Illustrated Dictionary of Dentistry, 1982).

A loosely defined grouping of drugs that have effects on psychological function. Here the psychotropic agents include the antidepressive agents, hallucinogens, and tranquilizing agents (including the antipsychotics and anti-anxiety agents).
The upper part of the trunk between the NECK and the ABDOMEN. It contains the chief organs of the circulatory and respiratory systems. (From Stedman, 25th ed)
Either of the pair of organs occupying the cavity of the thorax that effect the aeration of the blood.

Enlargement of the HEART, usually indicated by a cardiothoracic ratio above 0.50. Heart enlargement may involve the right, the left, or both HEART VENTRICLES or HEART ATRIA. Cardiomegaly is a nonspecific symptom seen in patients with chronic systolic heart failure (HEART FAILURE) or several forms of CARDIOMYOPATHIES.
Ultrasonic recording of the size, motion, and composition of the heart and surrounding tissues. The standard approach is transthoracic.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
The valve between the left atrium and left ventricle of the heart.
A living entity.

Definition: A factor, such as a microorganism, chemical substance, or form of radiation, whose presence, excessive presence, or (in deficiency diseases) relative absence is essential, in whole or in part, for the occurrence of a condition.

Constraint: The use of this participation is limited to observations.
